title: Zeita, Tulkarm
text:
Zeita () is a <a href="Palestinian%20people">Palestinian</a> town in the <a href="Tulkarm%20Governorate">Tulkarm Governorate</a> in the western <a href="West%20Bank">West Bank</a>, located 11 kilometers North-east of <a href="Tulkarm">Tulkarm</a>. According to the <a href="Palestinian%20Central%20Bureau%20of%20Statistics">Palestinian Central Bureau of Statistics</a>, Zeita had a population of 2,852 inhabitants in 2007. 21.5% of the population of Zeita were refugees in 1997. The healthcare facilities for Zeita are designated as MOH level 2.
History.
Zeita is an ancient village where marble <a href="Corinthian%20order">Corinthian</a> <a href="Capital%20%28architecture%29">capital</a>s have been reused in a local <a href="Maqam%20%28shrine%29">Maqam</a>.
Pottery remains have been found here from the <a href="Byzantine%20Empire">Byzantine</a>, early <a href="Muslim">Muslim</a> and the Middle Ages.
In 1265, Zeita was among the villages and estates sultan <a href="Baibars">Baibars</a> allocated to his <a href="amir">amir</a>s after he had expelled the <a href="Crusader%20States">Crusaders</a>. Half of Zaita was given to <a href="emir">emir</a> "Jamal al-Din Aidughdi al-'Azizi", a quarter to emir "Shams al-Din Ildikuz al-Karaki", and a quarter to emir "Saif al-Din Qilij al-Baghdadi".
Ottoman era.
The village was incorporated into the <a href="Ottoman%20Empire">Ottoman Empire</a> with the rest of <a href="Palestine%20%28region%29">Palestine</a> in 1517. In the 1596 Ottoman <a href="Defter">tax records</a>, it appeared under the name of Zaita, located in the <a href="Nahiya">Nahiya</a> <a href="Qaqun">Qaqun</a>, in the <a href="Nablus%20Sanjak">Nablus Sanjak</a>. It had a population of 91 <a href="Muslim">Muslim</a> and 7 <a href="Christians">Christian</a> households. They paid a fixed tax-rate of 33.3% on agricultural products, including wheat, barley, summer crops, olive trees, goats and beehives, in addition to occasional revenues and a press for olive oil or grape syrup and a tax on people in the Nablus area; a total of 3,440 <a href="ak%C3%A7e">akçe</a>. Pottery remains from the Ottoman era have also been found here.
Zeita appears on sheet 45 <a href="Pierre%20Jacotin">Jacotin's</a> map drawn-up during <a href="Napoleon">Napoleon</a>'s <a href="French%20campaign%20in%20Egypt%20and%20Syria">invasion in 1799</a>, though its position is not accurate. 
During the 1834 <a href="Peasants%27%20revolt%20in%20Palestine">Peasants' revolt in Palestine</a>, <a href="Ibrahim%20Pasha%20of%20Egypt">Ibrahim Pasha of Egypt</a> pursued rebels to Zeita. Ninety rebels were slain here, while the rest fled to nearby <a href="Deir%20al-Ghusun">Deir al-Ghusun</a>. At Deir al-Ghusun, many of the inhabitants and rebels heeded a call by <a href="Husayn%20Abd%20al-Hadi">Husayn Abd al-Hadi</a> to flee once the Egyptian troops arrived. In response, rebel commander <a href="Qasim%20al-Ahmad">Qasim</a> had several of the defectors among his ranks killed. Ibrahim Pasha's troops stormed the hill and the rebels (mostly members of the Qasim, <a href="Jarrar%20clan">Jarrar</a>, <a href="Jayyusi%20clan">Jayyusi</a> and Barqawi clans) were routed, suffering 300 fatalities. In 1838 it was noted as a village, Zeita, in the western "Esh-Sha'rawiyeh" administrative region, north of <a href="Nablus">Nablus</a>.
In 1870 <a href="Victor%20Gu%C3%A9rin">Victor Guérin</a> found here a village with 600 inhabitants. He further noted: "Here I found, just as at <a href="Jatt%2C%20Israel">Jett</a>, an ancient <a href="Capital%20%28architecture%29">capital</a> hollowed out to make a <a href="Mortar%20and%20pestle">mortar</a>, and used for the same purpose. A very good <a href="Water%20well">well</a>, constructed of cut stone, seems ancient."
In 1882, the <a href="Palestine%20Exploration%20Fund">PEF</a>'s "<a href="PEF%20Survey%20of%20Palestine">Survey of Western Palestine</a>" (SWP) described it as: "a good-sized village on high ground at the edge of the plain. It is surrounded with fig-gardens, and has olives to the south. It would appear to be an ancient place, having tombs to the east. The supply is principally from wells, but there is a small spring ('Ain esh Shabutbut) on the south-west. [..] Two sacred places exist to the south side of the village."
British Mandate era.
In the <a href="1922%20census%20of%20Palestine">1922 census of Palestine</a> conducted by the <a href="Mandatory%20Palestine">British Mandate authorities</a>, Zeita had a population of 1,087, all Muslims, increasing in the <a href="1931%20census%20of%20Palestine">1931 census</a> to 1,165 persons, all Muslim, living in 237 houses.
In the <a href="Village%20Statistics%2C%201945">1945 statistics</a> the population of Zeita was 1,780 Muslims, with 6,410 <a href="dunam">dunam</a>s of land according to an official land and population survey. 782 dunams were plantations and irrigable land, 5,120 used for cereals, while 33 dunams were built-up (urban) land.
Jordanian era.
In the wake of the <a href="1948%20Arab%E2%80%93Israeli%20War">1948 Arab–Israeli War</a>, and after the <a href="1949%20Armistice%20Agreements">1949 Armistice Agreements</a>, Zeita came under <a href="Jordan">Jordan</a>ian rule, together with the rest of the <a href="West%20Bank">West Bank</a>.
In 1961, the population was 1,814 persons.
Post-1967.
After the <a href="Six-Day%20War">Six-Day War</a> in 1967, Zeita has been under <a href="Israeli%20occupation%20of%20the%20West%20Bank">Israeli occupation</a>.
